title: Mine, Yamaguchi
text:
is a <a href="Cities%20of%20Japan">city</a> located in <a href="Yamaguchi%20Prefecture">Yamaguchi Prefecture</a>, <a href="Japan">Japan</a>. As of May 1, 2016, the city has an estimated <a href="population">population</a> of 25,857 and a <a href="population%20density">population density</a> of 54.70 persons per km2. The total area is 472.71 km2.
History.
The city was founded on March 31, 1954 by a merger of municipalities that departed from <a href="Mine%20District%2C%20Yamaguchi">Mine District</a> ("Mine-gun"). 
On March 21, 2008, Mine absorbed the rest of <a href="Mine%20District%2C%20Yamaguchi">Mine District</a>, which consisted of towns <a href="Mit%C5%8D%2C%20Yamaguchi">Mitō</a> and <a href="Sh%C5%ABh%C5%8D%2C%20Yamaguchi">Shūhō</a>, while the newly merged city retained the name, Mine.
Geology.
The plateau consists of uplifted reef <a href="limestone">limestone</a>s of <a href="Paleozoic">Paleozoic</a> age, which were thickened by <a href="Fold%20%28geology%29">overfolding</a> during the Akiyoshidai orogenic movement. Subsequent erosion has created an undulating <a href="karst">karst</a> landscape dimpled with many <a href="Sinkhole">doline</a>s and countless limestone pinnacles up to two meters in height. Beneath the surface lie hundreds of caves, a few of them quite significant geologically.
Numerous fossils of <a href="Pleistocene">Pleistocene</a> age have been found in these caves, including those of the Japanese <a href="rhinoceros">rhinoceros</a>, <a href="Stegodon">Stegodon</a>t elephant, <a href="Naumann%20elephant">Naumann elephant</a>, Young <a href="tiger">tiger</a>, and numerous other animals from the last interglacial period.
The area around Akiyoshidai was once heavily forested about 500,000 years ago. In the <a href="J%C5%8Dmon%20period">Jōmon period</a>, the area served as a hunting ground and the bottoms of <a href="sinkhole">sinkhole</a>s as vegetable fields. Numerous <a href="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> artifacts have been recovered. As farming began in Japan, the local people eventually replaced the forested landscape with <a href="Japanese%20pampas%20grass">Japanese pampas grass</a> for feeding their animals and thatching houses. Repeated cycles of burning the grass have kept trees from growing back since.
